page.title: 09Heather Manor House
page.content: The Manor House, a Grade 2 listed building, an early instance of specialised planning and a well preserved example of its style, stands to the South of the Church. It was built about 1730 on the site of an earlier farmhouse, which had been built on the site of the Commandery of the Knights of St. John. Traces of the original stone foundations are extant in the cellar. Original Georgian fittings include doors, stone fireplace surrounds, moulded cornices, pine panelling in one room and re-used 17th Century oak panelling in another. A scullery, added in Victorian times, has been removed, but a Music Room, added to the North side, still remains. In the garden there are wrought iron gates, with vine leaves, brought from Gopsall Hall in 1951.
